scheme

Class StringManip

  • java.lang.Object
    • scheme.StringManip

  • public class StringManip
extends Object
    Utility class which provides functions for working with Strings within scheme.

    • Method Detail

      • typify

        public static Map.Entry<Class<?>,String> typify(String data,
                                                boolean bool01,
                                                boolean commonTypes,
                                                boolean postfixFL,
                                                boolean parseDates)
        Attempts to parse a given String of data and infer the type of information it represents.

        Using the _.parse_(String) methods for _ = Byte, Short, etc., this method finds the narrowest type of (Boolean, Byte, Short, Integer, Long, Float, Double, Character, LocalDateTime, String, in that order) which can be used to losslessly represent the data contained in the provided data String. The inferred class of the interpreted data and the (possibly modified) argument itself are then returned in an Entry<Class, String>, where the first argument is the class which has been inferred and the second argument is the (possibly modified) user-supplied data.

        null or empty data Strings are assigned class Object and the returned data will be null. data Strings which consist only of whitespace will be assigned class String and the data will be returned as-is. Otherwise, leading and trailing whitespace will be trimmed with String.trim(), any surrounding double- or single-quotes will be removed, and whitespace will be trimmed again. If the resulting String is a single non-whitespace, non-numeric character, the returned class will be Character. Any user-supplied string which consists of only (optional) whitespace and a single pair of matching single or double quotes will also be returned as-is and classed as a String.

        The bool01 flag will interpret '0' and '1' as false and true, respectively. If this flag is disabled, they will instead be interpreted as Bytes. The characters '0' through '9' will also be interpreted as Bytes, unless the commonTypes flag is enabled. The commonTypes flag restricts the returned class to just four classes -- Boolean, String, Double, and LocalDateTime (the latter, provided that parseDates is set to true).

        The postfixFL flag allows for the interpretation of explicit floats and longs. If the String contains an integer immediately followed by an 'l' or an 'L', it will be interpreted as a Long (ex: "42L"). If it contains a floating-point number immediately followed by an 'f' or an 'F', it will be interpreted as a Float (ex: "42f").

        If the provided data cannot be parsed as any of the eight primitive wrapper classes, it will be returned as-is (without being stripped of surrounding whitespace or quotes, as a String, unless it can be parsed as a LocalDateTime, and the parseDates flag is enabled. Recognition of date-time-formatted Strings is handled by DateTimeFormats. To check which date-time formats are currently being recognized, use DateTimeFormats.strings() or DateTimeFormats.get(). If the given data String is not recognized as any other type, then when it's parsed as a LocalDateTime, an attempt will be made to match it against every recognised date-time format in the order that they are stored, until one succeeds. For this reason, you should only add date-time formats which you expect to encounter while parsing your file(s) of interest.

        For thorough categorization of data Strings, commonTypes should be set to false and parseDates should be set to true. For fast categorization of data Strings, commonTypes should be set to true and parseDates should be set to false.

        Usage:

        First, define some aliases for brevity's sake: 
        
 jshell> import static scheme.StringManip.typify
 jshell> boolean T = true
 jshell> boolean F = false
        null and empty Strings are returned as null Objects: 
        
 jshell> typify(null, T, F, T, F)
 $14 ==> class java.lang.Object=null

 jshell> typify("", T, F, T, F)
 $15 ==> class java.lang.Object=null
        Mismatched single- or double-quotes are returned as Characters (after whitespace is trimmed): 
        
 jshell> typify(" ' \b", T, F, T, F)
 $16 ==> class java.lang.Character='

 jshell> typify("\t \"\r", T, F, T, F)
 $17 ==> class java.lang.Character="
        data containing only whitespace and matched quotes are returned as-is: 
        
 jshell> typify(" ' ' ", T, F, T, F)
 $18 ==> class java.lang.String= ' '

 jshell> typify("' '", T, F, T, F)
 $19 ==> class java.lang.String=' '
        '0' and '1' are returned as Booleans if bool01 (the first flag) is set to true: 
        
 jshell> typify("0", T, F, T, F)
 $20 ==> class java.lang.Boolean=false

 jshell> typify("1", T, F, T, F)
 $21 ==> class java.lang.Boolean=true
        ...and they're returned as Bytes otherwise: 
        
 jshell> typify("0", F, F, T, F)
 $22 ==> class java.lang.Byte=0

 jshell> typify("1", F, F, T, F)
 $23 ==> class java.lang.Byte=1
        ...unless commonTypes (the second flag) is enabled: 
        
 jshell> typify("0", F, T, T, F)
 $24 ==> class java.lang.Double=0.0

 jshell> typify("1", F, T, T, F)
 $25 ==> class java.lang.Double=1.0
        There are a few hard-coded aliases for false as well: 
        
 jshell> typify("false", F, T, T, F)
 $26 ==> class java.lang.Boolean=false

 jshell> typify("False", F, T, T, F)
 $27 ==> class java.lang.Boolean=false

 jshell> typify("FALSE", F, T, T, F)
 $28 ==> class java.lang.Boolean=false

        ...and similar ones for true.

        Postfixes for longs and floats are recognized when postfixFL (the third flag) is set to true:

        
 jshell> typify("42L", F, F, T, F)
 $29 ==> class java.lang.Long=42

 jshell> typify("42f", F, F, T, F) $30 ==> class java.lang.Float=42.0
        ...and they're categorised as Strings otherwise: 
        
 jshell> typify("42l", F, F, F, F)
 $31 ==> class java.lang.String=42l

 jshell> typify("42F", F, F, F, F)
 $32 ==> class java.lang.String=42F
        Numbers are boxed into the smallest available type, based on the ranges of each class: 
        
 jshell> typify("2", F, F, F, F)
 $33 ==> class java.lang.Byte=2

 jshell> typify("200", F, F, F, F)
 $34 ==> class java.lang.Short=200

 jshell> typify("2e9", F, F, F, F)
 $35 ==> class java.lang.Integer=2000000000

 jshell> typify("5e9", F, F, F, F)
 $36 ==> class java.lang.Long=5000000000

 jshell> typify("5e25", F, F, F, F)
 $37 ==> class java.lang.Float=5.0E25

 jshell> typify("5e99", F, F, F, F)
 $38 ==> class java.lang.Double=5.0E99

 jshell> typify("5e999", F, F, F, F)
 $39 ==> class java.lang.String=5e999

        ...note that, if commonTypes (the second flag) were enabled, all of the above would be categorised as Doubles, except for the last one, which is outside the range of Double. Also note that exponential notation ('e'/'E') normally isn't allowed in Java for integral types (int or long), but it's been added here.

        Numbers can also contain '_' and ',' as thousands separators and they will be correctly parsed by this method, but any number containing a decimal point will be parsed as a float as the narrowest possible type:

        
 jshell> typify("2,000", F, F, F, F)
 $40 ==> class java.lang.Short=2000

 jshell> typify("60_000_000_000", F, F, F, F)
 $41 ==> class java.lang.Long=60000000000

 jshell> typify("60_000.0", F, F, F, F)
 $42 ==> class java.lang.Float=60000.0

        If the user hasn't added any date-time formats and attempts to parse a String with parseDates enabled, the default formats are added to the list of recognised formats:

        
 jshell> import static scheme.DateTimeFormats.*

 jshell> strings() $43 ==> []

 jshell> typify("1976-04-01 21:12:00", F, F, F, T) $44 ==> class
 java.time.LocalDateTime=1976-04-01 21:12:00

 jshell> strings() $45 ==> [yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss, yyyy/MM/dd
 HH:mm:ss.SS, MM/dd/yyyy hh:mm:ss a, M/d/yy H:mm, dd/MM/yyyy
 HH:mm:ss]
        If parseDates is disabled, date-formatted Strings will be returned as-is as Strings: 
        
 jshell> typify("1976-04-01 21:12:00", F, F, F, F)
 $46 ==> class java.lang.String=1976-04-01 21:12:00
        Parameters:
        data - raw String data to interpret
        bool01 - if true, '0' and '1' are interpreted as booleans
        commonTypes - if true, the returned class will only be one of four "common" classes -- Boolean, String, Double, and LocalDateTime
        postfixFL - if true, explicit floats and longs (i.e. "1.1F" or "13l") will be interpreted, otherwise, they're interpreted as Strings
        parseDates - if true, date-time-formatted Strings will be interpreted as LocalDateTimes, otherwise, they'll be left as Strings
        Returns:
        the inferred class of the information contained in the data String and that data itself (possibly slightly modified) in an Entry<Class, String>.

      • makeValidIdentifier

        public static String makeValidIdentifier(String text)
        Attempts to transform the given text into an identifier / variable name which is maximally compatible across languages / systems.

        Removes all non-alphanumeric, non-underscore characters from the given text, ensures that the initial character is alphabetic (ASCII), and trims all leading / trailing underscores and whitespace. If the resulting String has length zero (or the initial text is null or has length zero), the string "X" will be returned.

        The resulting identifiers are valid in all JVM languages, as well as the R language and SQL.

        Parameters:
        text - text to transform into an identifier
        Returns:
        the transformed text

      • stringAsDate

        public static LocalDateTime stringAsDate(String date)
        Attempts to parse the given String as a LocalDateTime.

        Loops over the list of LocalDateTime formats defined in DateTimeFormats and attempts to parse the given String as a date-time string using each format, in order.

        The first format in the list which can interpret the String as a date will be used to create and return a LocalDateTime object, even if there is a more specific format further down the list. Use DateTimeFormats.add(java.util.Locale, String) and DateTimeFormats.remove(int) to adjust the list of recognised date-time formats to your needs.

        Parameters:
        date - String to be interpreted as a date-time
        Returns:
        date, parsed as a LocalDateTime, if possible, otherwise, null
